column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=2. Thermodynamically Constrained Averaging Theory
#Text=A wide range of length scales exist and the terminology used to describe these length scales varies in the literature .
#Text=For our purposes , three discrete length scales are of concern to support the discussion that follows .
#Text=The microscale is a length scale that is long compared to the mean distance between molecular collisions or the vibrational scale for a solid .
#Text=At the microscale a point represents an averaging region that is related to the lower bound on the length scale needed for the laws of continuum mechanics to apply .
#Text=Another characteristic of the microscale is that a point exists entirely within an individual phase , even in a system that includes multiphase phases ( fluids , solids ) .
#Text=Porous medium systems are systems that contain multiple phases by definition .
#Text=At the microscale , the morphology and topology of the phase distributions are resolved in time .
#Text=For porous medium systems , the microscale is oftentimes referred to as the pore scale .
#Text=The second scale of concern herein is the macroscale .

#Text=The macroscale is a scale where phase distributions are resolved only in an averaged sense ; a point is the centroid of an averaging region which extends over all phases , interfaces , common curves , and common points that exist in a system .
#Text=Macroscale extent measures involve concepts such as volume fractions , fluid saturations , specific interfacial areas , and specific common curve lengths .
#Text=The boundaries of the phases are not resolved at the macroscale , only the averaged extent measures are resolved .

#Text=Macroscale representations are necessary to make many systems of interest tractable , including engineered systems such as filters and reactors and natural systems such as subsurface porous medium systems , including petroleum reservoirs .

#Text=This is so because even for cases in which microscale details of phase distribution are accessible , computational limitations of even the world ’s fastest computers precludes the detailed simulations of systems at the scale of applications of concern , say the unsaturated zone above an aquifer .
#Text=Macroscale representations are also used as a simplification when microscale details are unnecessary for the problem of interest .

#Text=The third scale of interest is termed the megascale , and it is the overall length scale of the system of concern , which might vary greatly in size between a model laboratory system , an engineered system , and a natural system .
#Text=What is common at the megascale however is that the details of the spatial distribution of quantities within the system are not resolved .
#Text=Instead , inputs and outputs from the system are considered only on the boundaries of the system .
#Text=Oftentimes systems may be considered megascale in one or two dimensions and say macroscale in the remaining dimensions .
#Text=An example of such an instance is the treatment of a subsurface region in a vertically averaged fashion ; only spatial variations in the horizontal plane are resolved .

#Text=The typical situation is that macroscale models are phenomenological in nature — meaning conservation equations are written following an assumed form usually based upon a presumed extension of microscale principles , which are better understood .
#Text=Then the macroscale models are typically closed using empirical relations intended to represent small-scale behavior in a simplified , yet meaningful and tractable manner .
#Text=The literature is replete with such examples , and flow and transport phenomena in porous medium systems is a prime class of example .

#Text=The phenomenological approach can lead to solvable systems that enable solutions , but the general procedure is fraught with problems , many of which are not well understood because the general approach is deeply ingrained in text books and practice , and generally accepted .
#Text=The phenomenological approach of model formulation suffers from several problems .
#Text=First , fundamental microscale physics may not be naturally and explicitly present in posited macroscale models .
#Text=Second , certain microscale principles , such as thermodynamics , are often completely ignored .

#Text=Third , quantities that appear in macroscale models may not be precisely defined in terms of microscale quantities , precluding a rigorous connection between microscale systems and macroscale systems .

#Text=Fourth , macroscale closure relations are often constructs of convenience intended to produce solvable systems but not deduced from fundamentals or constrained to obey thermodynamic principles , such as the second law of thermodynamics .

#Text=Fifth , phenomenological models are typically evaluated and validated by comparing to the overall system of concern , and when they fail to provide an adequate description a new model must be formulated without a rigorous , well-defined procedure to do so .
#Text=TCAT has been developed to resolve these issues associated with standard phenomenological approaches .
